story:
My name is Doug Youngs, or Douglas H Youngs as it appears on the cover of my book. I am a first time self-published author. At age 61 my thoughts when I chose to self-publish my work were of a sense of urgency. I have had a love of writing and of books all my life and tried going the traditional route to get something published but after years of frustration and rejection letters I gave up on the idea. In order to get published going the traditional route you have to submit a manuscript and then wait for moths for an extreme stroke of luck to fall into your lap. The truth is unless you have already been published and are represented by an agent that is good at what he or she does you will be lucky if you get a rejection letter that isn't of the cold hearted form letter type. Writing is a tough business to break into.

In 1993 I turned away from trying to get published and decided after years of resisting to go to college. The idea represented an opportunity to write a lot and get some attention while working in an environment that offered critical feedback and coaching. College offered a chance to write plays, poems, shirt stories, research papers, study the purpose of a story as the great authors of old approached their writing, and write a full length novel. The adventure that was my college experience renewed my desire to write and get published and all I needed was that right story, and The Regulators: Hell On earth is that story.

It was easy when I finished the book, which became a two book set due to the length of the story but then I discovered something most people don't see, and that is that in order for your book to be anything more than a wasted listing with a seller you have to promote your work. Getting published doesn't mean instant fame or riches because no one knows your book is here without the eve harder job of making it visible to millions of people, and it is even more difficult for self-published authors.

The most important part of promotions is getting the attention of major newspapers. The can tell the millions of people you want to reach who you are and what you have done, and they can offer a review that will attract the interest of the readers you want. The thing is most of the newspapers such as my Big 5 will not even bother with a self-published author. We are talking about The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Chicago Tribune, The LA Times and USA Today. A book review by a paper like the New York Times bring your book the attention of millions of readers and a good review delivers instant credibility among readers who will buy your book.

The problem with reaching newspapers is you have to be able to pay to have quality press releases written in order to get newspapers' attention, and you have to be able to pay for printed copies of your book to send to the papers which also requires paying for shipping. In order to have a decent chance at reaching the large number of people you are targeting you realistically have to approach a large number of papers, and you can pay for a service that will share your press release with hundreds of news sources, but being able to pay for the service is the sticking point. It takes money.

Other promotional possibilities include trade fairs, book conventions and book signings, and getting listed on literary websites on the Internet. Again, these all cost money, for printing copies to use at signings and shows, for fees that begins as low as $50 per month on websites and for travel to shows and signings. A book tour is expensive.

Without the money to afford real promotion efforts The Regulators: Hell On earth has done poorly. I have sold two print copies, three Kindle versions, purchased several print copies for promotional purposes, including 2 copies that have gone to newspapers, one being the little hometown paper that did print a story on the third page of the paper, and 154 free Kindle copies I gave away for a promotion. Business is booming without real promotions. The local papers story did attract attention, yes it did, but in a small market the story translated into $0 in sales.

I met someone on a movie fan website where I posted a story that mentioned my book to try and get attention and he, like me, is a self-published author who is now using IndiegGoGo to fund a movie project based on the book he published and suggested giving it a try. here I am now, throwing myself on the mercy of the court, as they say because The Regulators: Hell On Earth is a good story, one worth taking a shot with and this right here is what my entire life has been about.

Thank You

My book has a very tiny audience, is not selling. To draw attention to the book there are costs. I can't afford the costs without help.
story_txt: My name is Doug Youngs, or Douglas H Youngs as it appears on the cover of my book. I am a first time self-published author. At age 61 my thoughts when I chose to self-publish my work were of a sense of urgency. I have had a love of writing and of books all my life and tried going the traditional route to get something published but after years of frustration and rejection letters I gave up on the idea. In order to get published going the traditional route you have to submit a manuscript and then wait for moths for an extreme stroke of luck to fall into your lap. The truth is unless you have already been published and are represented by an agent that is good at what he or she does you will be lucky if you get a rejection letter that isn't of the cold hearted form letter type. Writing is a tough business to break into.In 1993 I turned away from trying to get published and decided after years of resisting to go to college. The idea represented an opportunity to write a lot and get some attention while working in an environment that offered critical feedback and coaching. College offered a chance to write plays, poems, shirt stories, research papers, study the purpose of a story as the great authors of old approached their writing, and write a full length novel. The adventure that was my college experience renewed my desire to write and get published and all I needed was that right story, and The Regulators: Hell On earth is that story.It was easy when I finished the book, which became a two book set due to the length of the story but then I discovered something most people don't see, and that is that in order for your book to be anything more than a wasted listing with a seller you have to promote your work. story:
Who we are:

Voices, Ink. (The Winnipeg Youth Poetry Slam Team) is a team of four talented  young ladies who have been selected to represent our city in the YouthCanSlam National poetry competition in mid-August. 

Eva Rodrigues (15), Shaden Abusaleh (17), Shahad Abdulrazaq (17) and Amber Leenders (19) competed in this year's city-wide poetry slams and ranked as the top four youth poets in Winnipeg!

The girls are so excited to travel to Ottawa for YouthCanSlam, the national youth poetry slam!  This is an incredible opportunity for them to meet other young poets, attend various workshops and poetry performances by nationally recognized poets, and best of all, represent Winnipeg in the national competition.

Voices, Ink. is a non-profit, volunteer-based organization dedicated to creating opportunities for youth poets.  Although we are gaining momentum as an organization, we are seeking support from the community to send our first-ever YOUTH POETRY SLAM TEAM to nationals!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Although we have fundraised (at the Winnipeg Youth Poetry Slams) for our team since January, we still need $500 in order to subsidize the cost of this expensive trip.  The total cost of the travel and accommodations is just over $2500  - which includes the flights (each $470) and the cost of our stay in Ottawa (a shared room at the U of O residence, which is $100/night).
Please help us out!  :)
  • Donate $10 and we will write you a haiku on a topic of your choice!
  • Donate $25 and we will write you a limerick on a topic of your choice!
  • Donate $50 to get a personalized sonnet!
  • Donate $100 and we will not only write a personalized slam poem for the recipient of your choice, but we will perform it, live at the recipient's home or workplace (within Winnipeg city limits only).

 

Risks & Challenges

The spoken word community in Winnipeg is small but strong!  In order to continue to grow the capacity of our youth poets we want to be able to participate in spoken word events on a national level.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute to our campaign, please help us out by getting the word out!  Please share our campaign with your friends / family!
